creator.name: Evangelische Broedergemeente
creator.his_func:
The Moravian Brethren (Hernhutters, Herrnhut - Germany) arrived in Suriname in 1735.
At first, they were allowed to work among the indigenous peoples and the Maroons. They founded the following mission stations: Pilgerhut (Berbice) and Saron, Ephrem/Hoop, (New)Bambey and Sommelsdyck in Suriname. Around 1830 they were allowed to start their missionary activities among the slaves on the plantations. The brotherhood had over 27,000 members in 1862; that was 70% of the slave population.
creator.notes: See also the "Repertorium van Nederlandse zendings- en missie-archieven 1800-1960", keyword Evangelische Broeder Gemeente.

Gegevens hieruit overbrengen naar een record EBG in archieffondsen HUA:

The EBG was characterized by a firm organization, a pious and industrious lifestyle and a great missionary activity. The missionaries were given the assignment to make notes about the population groups they visited, each with their own cultural and religious backgrounds. For this reason their notes are an important addition to the archives of the colonial government.
